review.des:
This place was pretty busy.

The service was superb! Very accommodating! The waiter was very helpful in a professional way which made you feel very comfortable asking him question or recommendation.

The tables are very close to each other, so be warned people can easily hear your conversation. In other words it is not the most romantic setting. I came with family and felt very relaxing.

The food were impressive but too salty for my taste and one of the family members.

Without the drink, I'd say $80/person easily. And we were all pretty full that we shared only one order of desert.

I would say it was a pretty pleasant experience over all!

This was my second time at Blackbird and I wanted to update my review of this restaurant. When first visit left us a little bit with mixing feelings, the second visit was splendid!! We chose to seat at the bar this time to have more interaction with bartenders and ask about drinks they were making. Sometimes the description of the drinks does not give you enough information to determine if it will be on the sweet, sour or bitter side. Sitting at the bar gives you a great opportunity to get a right drink for yourself :) The amus bouche was excellent inviting you to what would happen next. The Rye bread served with delicious and silky spread is a staple before a dinner. We ordered:

1. Gently Smoked Cobia served with consomme-very interesting dish. You can definitely taste the smoke flavor infused to the flakes of the fish. A lot o flavors combined and yet balanced with ginger consomme.

2. Dry Aged Beef Tartare with walnuts and parmesan-definitely well made beef tartare. If you are a fan of beef tartare, you will not be disappointed.

3. Truffled Shrimp and Lobsterau pain with horseradish and cured egg yolk-this was a heaven on dish. The idea of combining the shrimp and lobster into one was beyond  imagination. This was so flavorful and tasty that we did not want it to end :) Buttery taste broken with the hint of horseradish was a very enjoyable dish.

4. Roasted Rohan Duck with deep fried carrots , foie gras and port wine was one of the best ducks I had so far. Perfect marriage. Meat was done to a perfect point and I liked the idea of deep fried carrots and foie gras definitely contributed well to the whole serving.

5. Rostaed Lamb Saddle with grapefruit, brussel sprouts and basil-my wife and I we love the lamb any way and this was the first time we had lamb saddle. Very flavorful most likely due to containing a little bit more fat, combining surprisingly well with grapefruit. Very compelling presentation of lamb!

Our dinner was accompanied with excellent drinks and I cannot name which one was the best of them as all were perfectly made. This was a superb experience in Blackbird that night. Thank you!!

Fantastic 3-course prix fixe lunch - glad I went with a friend who was willing to share!  Perfect size and (as others have said), a great inexpensive way to try a Michelin starred restaurant.  Food was great from start (sourdough bread and honey butter) to middle (butternut squash, fried cod with incredibly flaky crust) to finish (pot de creme).

Only downsides:  VERY tightly spaced tables (they have to pull them out for you to get into the booth side) and noisy construction outside

Well deserved 5-stars! Blackbird is an eloquent, yet accessible, fine dining experience.

We came with a large group from work on a Friday night, and had made a reservation weeks prior. This place gets pretty busy, and doesn't have a TON of seats, so would recommend you do the same. Staff was very accommodative in getting us settled.

The tasting menu for dinner is $140 and features 10 courses. I unfortunately couldn't participate as it would have been too much trouble to ask for 3-4 substitutions (I'm allergic to shellfish), but I recommend you do. I think the cuisine is technically "American" but definitely has some french infusions.

I opted for the tartare for a starter, which was good, perhaps not best I've ever had. Where I think they really marveled was with their mains, where I ordered the beef strip, and was AMAZED at the combination of textures and flavors they pulled together. The hint of vanilla was certainly bold, and unique. When they serve you, there's a fun surprise (which I won't spoil) that was executed with perfection. Service was phenomenal throughout. They also serve bread for a first course, which was accompanied by a sweet honey butter, with a perfect texture. My peers got the squab, and the Cabbage for mains, both getting solid reviews.

You could share dishes if you wanted to, but perhaps not as easy to do as some other locations in the area. An app, entre and dessert would be a filling, not sickening spread for somebody who is hungry.

For dessert, the team shared a bunch of dishes. I personally opted for the pumpkin cake (seasonal woo!), per the servers recommendation, though the mochi donut and ganache are fan-favorites, apparently.

The wine list is robust, with offerings from AUS, USA, GER, FRA, and ITL amongst others. Dress is "smart casual." Blazers certainly are necessary, but would avoid hats, and t-shirts, if possible. Great spot for a third date, or dinner with the family/parents, as the prices are reasonable, yet the restaurant decor offers a scintillating feeling of elegance.

Just invited Mom and a lawyer to have lunch here. We celebrated my new job in a big law firm.
it is an one star Michelin restaurant. The service here is perfect. one of the appetizer is shrimp balls. It not only looks nice，but also tastes good! We all like the deer and sea food. The sculpt of the dessert is good.

This is the best lunch deal in Chicago.  Take someone you love.  I recommend the salad, fish and dessert.  Wine is very reasonable here.  I've also been here for dinner and ran up a huge tab but the reality is the lunch pre fixe is the steal of the century.  This is a no brainer to go if you want to take a loved one to a high quality meal.  

The service here is impeccable and the quality of the food and ambience is top notch.  I like it better than avec next door and I love avec.  Ha make sure to check this place out.

Great place to feel bougie without being judged for being a commoner. Service is great, staff is attentive, and the snack freebies make you feel special (I.e. extra small bite at the beginning and end).

I came here for the 10 course meal as part of a celebration. The price is steep, but if you don't do it often and enjoy beautiful plating and unique foodie stories to tell others, then it's worth trying at least once.

The first time we came here was during restaurant week, which I thought was just an OK experience. I thought the tasting menu this time was much better. I hope to come back for lunch sometime.

review.des:
5 stars for prix fixe lunch, 4 stars for dinner tasting menu.

Lunch is a great value. High quality bread and butter, appetizer, entree, and dessert for 25USD. Not as seasonal as some other restaurants but the menu changes every few months. Appetizers range from beef tartare, to soups, salads, or wonderfully prepared vegetables. This is what I believe to be the best value lunch in downtown in Chicago.

We had the 10 course winter tasting menu. The pastry chef wonderfully accommodated for dietary restrictions for one of the guests with an entirely different and wonderful tasting substitution. Unfortunately, while no dish was poorly executed, nothing particularly wowed us in either taste or concept.

My favourite of the night was the "moose tracks" venison with a chocolate paste reminiscent of mole, but it was a dish that was reminiscent of a lunch strip steak offering made the same way.

Good, sometimes great food, not worth the price for dinner. Though I still recommend it above all else for lunch.

I dined here for my birthday back in August, and I meant to write this review sooner and to be honest I thought I already had. I came down to Chicago with my parents specifically to have the tasting menu and originally we weren't going to do the wine pairing, but decided once we got to the restaurant to do it despite ourselves. It was absolutely worth both the trip down and the $200 a person with the wine. The seasonal tasting menu has obviously changed since I was there, but the 12 course summer menu was one of the best meals I have ever had. Chef Ryan and his crew absolutely nailed every dish, and the wine pairings were spot on. The Somme was friendly, knowledgeable, and prompt. Every person we encountered was courteous and professional. At one point, it started raining outside and some smokers had dipped under the awning over the entrance and my mom made a comment about the smoke coming into the dining room. Our server overheard, and walked out and asked them politely to move on. The ambience is modern and contemporary yet warm and inviting. And the chairs were very comfy, as the whole tasting took about three hours. Every course was served to everyone at the table at the same time, as a proper restaurant of this caliber should. Also, the food. It was all so very good. And the portions were definitely enough, certainly we did not leave hungry. From start to finish, we were absolutely blown away by each dish complemented perfectly with its paired wine. By the end of the meal we were all jolly and full. Afterward, I went up to the line where chef Ryan was expediting and shook his hand and he was also very polite and humble. This place is killing it, and their star is well deserved. I think another star is in their future on this track. It was an absolutely flawless meal from start to finish. I would recommend this place to anyone with the dough to spend, as no one should leave disappointed.

Great value for their prix fixe weekday lunch menu, 3 courses for $25.

The food made for a fun dining experience.

Started with bread service, a malted oat sourdough with a whipped butter spread, dense crumb, still delicious.

Green garlic falafel - while I enjoy crunchy textures, the falafels had too hard pieces that I would only recommend this to people of stalwart teeth.

Roasted whitefish - enjoyed

Kaffir lime scone - pass on the whipped cream inside

Would need to try more of their items to rank higher. Friendly service except for in the beginning. Thought it was weird how the host didn't greet and instead helped 2 other parties that walked in right after me.

Roasted whitefish - caramelized yogurt, endive, rhubarb kosho
Green garlic falafel - dill pickle, sweet fish sauce, sorrel

review.des:
Great value for quality and quantity. Would absolutely come back. $25 for a 3 course meal at a Michelin is crazy!

The meal started off with some sourdough bread with a brilliant honey infused butter. I got the shrimp salad which was cooked to perfection, extremely tender, and large. The duck confit came with some nice white sauce and had just the right amount of greens to fight off the richness of the dish. The meal ended with what seemed like a deconstructed apple pie with olive oil ice cream.

The service was extremely friendly and professional. Great experience overall for an unbeatable price.

I must start my review saying this is a fantastic restaurant.  It's classy, refined and creative.  The staff is extremely knowledgeable about the cuisine and very friendly.  So you ask why not a perfect 5 stars... well you will see.  To start I had the most wonderful lobster and horseradish spread on grilled fresh bread.  It was absolutely divine and decadent.  Who would have ever imagined that lobster and horseradish went together so well???  Here is where things went downhill.  My main was the steak from the menu.  I love steak, I mean, I love steak, all kinds of cuts but this piece of striploin was slightly under par.  I think it was cooked sous vide then gilled.  Here was the issues I had with it:  It could have been grilled a bit more to give a bit of crust and flavor and the peice of meet was a very stringy.  I had to really chew it.  Don't get me wrong this was an excellent sourced piece of meat, but just by cutting in half you could tell it may not have been the best in house that night.  Small blemish on the entire meal.  My dessert consisted of something I love most... CHEESE.  So good paired with a nice glass of Cabernet.  All in all, an excellent meal.  Would have been perfect if the star of the meal would have been selected better.  STILL A MUST TRY IN CHICAGO

(4.5 stars)

While it doesn't differentiate itself too much from other one-starred Michelin restaurants, the quality of the food and service at Blackbird make it an excellent restaurant.

At my last visit, I enjoyed the shrimp and lobster appetizer and the delicious lamb saddle for my entrée. Both dishes were prepared very well, punctuated by great flavor and balance. Blackbird serves up some good drinks as well. Consider the "Trust Us," which is Blackbird's drink of the day. As the name suggests, you don't need to ask what the drink is before ordering. (It'll probably be good either way!)

The main dining area isn't large by any means, but at least during my last visit, it didn't feel cramped, even as the restaurant began to fill up. It's certainly minimalist in design, but there's a certain warmth about the space that lends itself to a nice ambience. Blackbird has a great private dining area upstairs also.

If you're looking for a restaurant at the cutting edge, then Blackbird isn't it. But, if you want superb food and service, then it certainly doesn't disappoint.

Had a very good meal at Blackbird, one of the better ones I've had in Chicago so far. Service was on point, as to be expected from a Michelin starred restaurant. The server was very helpful with her recommendations, attentive, always around when I needed her and very friendly. And they had many others constantly refilling waters, taking plates, etc. Courses were perfectly timed and the experience was great.

The meal started with the house made bread. I don't understand how, but this was one of my favorite bites of the night. I had them bring more. I can't remember what the bread was that day (I want to say a type of sourdough), but it was warm, had perfect texture, and was served with the perfect consistency celery infused butter which worked.

The amuse bouche was also a great starter - delicious falafel that had great texture on the outside, but was perfectly moist on the inside, served with a delicious pesto.

For dinner, I ordered the wagyu beef and porchetta. The wagyu had tons of flavors on the plate - salty, sweet, and everything in between. There were sweet potato chips, sour pickled red onions. The meat was perfectly tender and cooked well, although a bit on the salty side. There was a lot going on but overall the dish was well balanced. The porchetta was very fatty (as expected). It was served with a citrus sauce, and there were pieces of grapefruit on the plate that made it light and fresh. It was served with kimchi kale which was warm and added a little kick to the dish. The cornbread on here (one of the cook's family recipes), was probably the best thing on the plate it was so good.

I was too full for dessert, but they finished the meal with some goodies and also sent me home with some. The cardamom biscotti was delicious, as were the fruit squares and chocolate. Overall a great meal and not too expensive.

Excellent experience with the hubby! Very romantic, quaint and sophisticated. Our tasting menu was delightful! We especially loved the crisp veal sweetbreads! I particularly remember my endive salad--refreshing and perfect! And their duck is divine--perfectly cooked, nicely crisp skin, not too fatty. Ugh, I just loved this place! And we both LOVED the hand soap in their bathrooms... it's in the details! LOL

Have been here more times than I can count for what I consider to be the best lunch deal in the city - 25$ 3 course prix fixe and bread/butter with food and service maintained at the 1 star experience you would expect here.  

On each and every occasion the service was delightful and elegant. The food was filling and absolutely at the caliber that one would expect at a restaurant that has held a star for this many years.  The food is delicious with clear technique driven cooking that truly succeeds.  I can only wait to try dinner here sometime...

Came here for dinner with colleagues. I had the clam tortelli and for dessert - a chocolate and white cake with raspberries. It was really delicious. I will definitely come back and check out the tasting menu.

One of my favorite restaurants in West Loop! I went to there with my girlfriend, so we could also try a little bit dishes from each other.
Appetizer is amazing, my favorite is Shrimp and Lobster au pain. I also tried Lamb tartare, it's my first time to try fresh lamb, it sound weird and tastes incredible.
As of entrees, we tried roasted lamb and grilled sturgeon. Sturgeon is good but I prefer the lamb.
The space is very large but the service is great.

I only came here for lunch but their lunch prix fixe for only $25 is so worth it! It was my last day in Chicago and I had only a few hours to spend. I've had Blackbird on my bucket list for forever and thought I might as well. I didn't know about the prix fixe menu until being there but it's such a great deal! The pre fixe includes an appetizer, entree, and dessert.

It's good to go with someone else so you can other different things and get to sample a bit of everything. I ordered the warm shrimp salad which I thought was the better appetizer. My boyfriend ordered the salad which was really good too but the shrimp was so buttery and good!

For entrees I ordered the whitefish and my boyfriend ordered the hanger steak. I loved both our dishes. There were strawberries in the hanger steak which I thought was a little weird but I thought it was an interesting taste combination.

I had such an amazing experience here for lunch the people were very nice and attentive. I want to come back to try their dinner next time!

Hi - such attentive service. Good guidance through the menu. The cheese plate is pretty amazing, and my guest's entree (the duck) was fantastic. I was guided to the cabbage plate (the vegetarian option) and it was oddly inedible -- just incredibly heavy on the vinegar. I didn't trust myself the night of -- I mean, who am I to question a Michelin starred restaurant? And I didn't want to make my guest uncomfortable, so I said I was full and took mine home for the next day. Still completely inedible. A $40 entree I basically threw away. I told the restaurant via email and I think what is most irritating about the whole thing is that they didn't respond. Really, I just suggested that since not many people probably order the veg option, they may want to re-taste it. But, no response. Kind of a bummer of a way to end the evening.

This was my first time dining at a Michelin restaurant for lunch and surely it didn't disappoint. The pre fixed meal was $25 dollars and it consisted off an appetizer, entree, and a dessert.

The warm shrimp salad was cooked to a nice tender texture and the flavors were very light and balanced.

The hanger steak was cooked to a perfect medium rare and the accompanying mole was very interesting in a good way. The truffle oil added a nice flavor to every bite.

The chocolate pudding wasn't overly sweet and it was the perfect amount to eat for a light lunch.

I also ordered a glass of the  corbieres rouge which I enjoyed very much.  For the amount that you are paying you will definitely get the best value in both service and taste!

Time to review my 1st Michelin Star experience.

I was celebrating my 1-ish year anniversary with my girlfriend and after being unable to obtain reservations at Alinea, we managed to secure a last minute reservation for Blackbird.

They had a 5 or 10-course tasting menu for us that evening to pick from, we opted for the 10-course, because why not?

Our 10 course tasting menu included-
1. Rhubarb, Green Coriander, Churro
2. Crab, Sunflower, Strawberry, Tamagoyaki, Caviar
3. Hiramasa, English Pea, Puffed Grains
4. Artichoke, Morel, Fromage Blanc
5. Sturgeon, Garlic, Almond
6. Lamb Meatball, Pickled Shrimp, Licorice
7. Rohan Duck Breast, Lavender, Patato
8. Passion Fruit, Jalepeno, Freeze Pop
9. Goats Milk Flan, Strawberry, Basil
10. Tonka Bean, Carob, Churro

The flavors, textures, how the food pairs, it messes with your taste buds.
It was fun eating every dish, component by component, and then mixing it all together to bring it all together. I'm not used to eating this kind of cuisine, so my mind was rattling the whole time, trying to familiarize the flavors we were eating. We also got some of the cocktails which were delicious as well. Looking back, I think I would have tried the wine pairing too.

We were seated near the back of the restaurant so it was interesting to see all the kitchen action and prep work for the various dishes. Service was amazing the entire evening and very informative about each of the dishes, especially for some of the ingredients we had never even heard of. Highly recommend trying it out!

Came in for lunch and did the $25 prix fixe menu (c'mon, that should be enough for 5 stars alone!) and was in awe of the quality of food.  To start, I ordered the mushroom velouxe and it was immediately clear to me the quality of meal I was going to indulge in.  Never would I have thought that I would enjoy pear in what was basically in between a mushroom soup and mushroom puree, but MAN was it good!  The pear was cut into spaghetti-like strands, which I thought was a perfect compliment to the very earthy mushroom flavor.  For my entree I ordered the chicken sausage which was a very unique dish that also blew me away.  Finally, for dessert I ordered the pumpkin pie with cream and ice cream, and it was a great way to end the meal.  I would be remiss if I didn't mention that even their french press coffee that was served with dessert was killer!  Walking out of there I couldn't believe that I had gotten a 3 course meal from a Michelin Star restaurant for $25.  There is no better bang for the buck in this city.

Our overall experience was excellent.  
Service was impeccable and just right.  The drink currant mood was outstanding and she requested it a little sweeter because I asked.  
The tempura asparagus was really delicious with the sauce on the side. However, I did note that it was heavily salted and didn't know if it was because my palate was used to the sweetness in the drink.  Then the roasted lamb saddle was just outstanding - perfect texture, perfectly roasted medium as I requested.  However, there was something in the sauce or the tempura snail that was extremely salty again, resulting in my having to have several glasses of water during the meal and all through the night.  There might even have been some MSG, although I am not sure.  I thought I was unnecessarily salt sensitive until I read other reviews and noticed I was not the solo diner to think everything was over salted.  The ingredients were so superb that it was not appropriate to over salt the entrees.  
The desserts were superb as always and my coconut sorbet made everything better.

BLUF: A New American restaurant that elevates your taste buds, taking you on a culinary adventure to a whole new world of food.

This contemporary American restaurant has become my new favorite place to eat! When first approaching the establishment, I noticed it had a chic and modern appearance not only on the outside but the inside as well. It had a clean design with simple, yet elegant decorations. The customer service was excellent as the host/hostess greeted us warmly, and our waitresses was attentive to our needs with wine selection and overall food.

There is an option to partake in a ten course tasting experience; however, we passed on the opportunity this time. We ordered two appetizers (ahi tuna poke, lobster/shrimp pain) and two dishes (lamb, monkfish). All I had to say after each dish was WOW. The pain had a crispy, buttery exterior with a fluffy, rich interior. Each bite kept getting better and better. And the tuna poke was so fresh as the sauce and tiny bacon bits perfectly complemented the fish, not overpowering it. The monkfish tasted so clean as if it was just caught prior to serving, and had a perfect pair with these tiny quinoa falafel balls. Our personal favorite of the night was the lamb. It. Was. Amazing. The lamb just melted in your mouth and had the perfect amount of "gamey" flavor that was not overwhelming. The puree and sauce just added to the lamb as you could taste a whole new flavor with sweet, salty, umami all wrapped in one.

Regardless of the dish, each bite was just another explosion of flavor making the experience just so surreal. This restaurant definitely lives up to its reputation, and I highly recommend coming here if you haven't checked it out. Thank you so much for a great experience here last night! I know I will be back in the future when I come to Chicago again!
